required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Hydrogen Inhalation for Health and Exercise Performance
clinical_study.official_title: Hydrogen Inhalation for Health and Exercise Performance

lead_sponsor.agency: University of Novi Sad, Faculty of Sport and Physical Education

clinical_study.source: University of Novi Sad, Faculty of Sport and Physical Education

brief_summary.textblock: In this randomized double-blind, placebo-controlled, crossover pilot trial, we evaluated the effects of 7-day H2 inhalation on exercise performance outcomes and serum hormonal and inflammation profiles in a cohort of young men and women.

detailed_description.textblock: All participants were allocated to receive either gaseous hydrogen (4%) or placebo (room air) by 20-min once-per-day inhalation for 7 days, with wash-out period of 7 days to prevent the residual effects of interventions across study periods. The primary treatment outcome was the change in running time-to-exhaustion from baseline to day 7. Additionally, assessment of other exercise performance endpoints and clinical chemistry biomarkers were performed at baseline and after 7 days after each intervention.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline running time-to-exhaustion at 7 days

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline maximal voluntary isometric strength at 7 days
Change from baseline serum insulin at 7 days
Change from baseline serum ghrelin at 7 days

intervention.description: Inhalation of room air for 20 min per day during 7 days
Inhalation of 4% hydrogen for 20 min per day during 7 days

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
Age â‰¥ 18 -35 years Body mass index 20 - 25 kg/m2 Free of major diseases Physically active Must be able to give written informed consent
Exclusion Criteria:
Use of any dietary supplements within 4 weeks before study commences Abnormal values for lab clinical chemistry (> 2 SD)

reference.citation: Aoki K, Nakao A, Adachi T, Matsui Y, Miyakawa S. Pilot study: Effects of drinking hydrogen-rich water on muscle fatigue caused by acute exercise in elite athletes. Med Gas Res. 2012 Jul 12;2:12. doi: 10.1186/2045-9912-2-12. eCollection 2012.
Ostojic SM. Serum alkalinization and hydrogen-rich water in healthy men. Mayo Clin Proc. 2012 May;87(5):501-2. doi: 10.1016/j.mayocp.2012.02.008.

Da Ponte A, Giovanelli N, Nigris D, Lazzer S. Effects of hydrogen rich water on prolonged intermittent exercise. J Sports Med Phys Fitness. 2018 May;58(5):612-621. doi: 10.23736/S0022-4707.17.06883-9. Epub 2017 Apr 26.

patient_data.ipd_description: We will provide IPD on our University repository site
